text.head: SUMMARY
text.p:
This publication was prepared to support the overall work of the OECD Health Care Quality Indicators
Project in developing a set of indicators that can be used to raise questions for investigation concerning the
quality of care across countries.
It provides a manual to facilitate cross national comparisons of indicators for patient safety through the
provision of detailed practical advice on calculating each indicator in a selected set of Patient Safety
Indicators (PSI) utilising national hospital administrative databases.
The selected indicators are:
text.table:
Area

Hospital-acquired infections
Infection due to medical care
Decubitus ulcer

Postoperative hip fracture
Postoperative pulmonary embolism (PE) or deep vein thrombosis
(DVT)
Postoperative sepsis
Technical difficulty with procedure
Postoperative respiratory failure
Iatrogenic pneumothorax
Sentinel events
Transfusion reaction
Foreign body left in during procedure
Obstetrics
Birth trauma -injury to neonate
Obstetric trauma – vaginal delivery with instrument
Obstetric trauma – vaginal delivery without instrument
Obstetric trauma -caesarean section
text.p: For each of these indicators, the manual provides:

• Generic coding and calculation instructions related to national hospital administrative databases,
• Cross walk from ICD 9 to ICD 10 codes for each indicator,
• Detailed definitions for calculation of indicators, and
• Flow charts for visualising the calculation process.

The manual was originally designed to support the calculation of patient safety indicators in a group of
countries volunteering to participate in the validation of the methodology. However it is anticipated that
the material presented will also be of interest to a wider audience, including researchers and experts
interested in the technical background and construction of the Patient Safety Indicators and other countries
looking to develop internationally comparable health care quality indicators.
text.head: RÉSUMÉ
text.table:
Cette publication a été préparée pour accompagner les travaux réalisés dans le cadre du Projet de l'OCDE
sur les indicateurs de la qualité des soins visant à développer un ensemble d'indicateurs auxquels on puisse
se référer pour s'interroger sur la qualité des soins et services de santé dans les différents pays.
Cette publication contient un manuel destiné à faciliter les comparaisons entre pays au regard d'indicateurs
de la sécurité des patients. On y trouve des indications concrètes précises sur la façon de calculer chacun
des indicateurs d'un ensemble d'indicateurs de la sécurité des patients (Patient Safety Indicators ou PSI)
établis à partir de bases de données hospitalières nationales.
Les indicateurs considérés sont les suivants :
Champ

Infections nosocomiales
Infections liées aux soins médicaux
Escarres de décubitus
Complications opératoires et
postopératoires
Complications d'anesthésie
Fracture de hanche postopératoire
Embolie pulmonaire (EP) ou thrombose veineuse profonde (TVP)
postopératoire
Septicémie postopératoire
Difficulté technique pendant l'intervention
Détresse respiratoire postopératoire
Pneumothorax iatrogène
Événements sentinelles
Réaction à une transfusion
Corps étranger laissé au cours d'une intervention
Obstétrique
Traumatisme à la naissance – traumatisme au nouveau-né
Traumatisme obstétrical au cours d'un accouchement par voie basse
avec instrument
Traumatisme obstétrical au cours d'un accouchement par voie basse
sans instrument
Traumatisme obstétrical au cours d'une césarienne
Pour chacun de ces indicateurs, le manuel fournit :
• Les instructions de codification et de calcul à partir des bases de données hospitalières nationales,
• Les correspondances entre la CIM--9 et la CIM--10 pour chaque indicateur,
• Des définitions détaillées pour le calcul des indicateurs, et
• Des graphiques pour visualiser le processus de calcul.
Le manuel a initialement été conçu pour étayer le calcul des indicateurs de la sécurité des patients dans un
groupe de pays volontaires pour participer à la validation de la méthodologie. Cependant, on s'attend que
les éléments présentés intéressent aussi un plus large public, à savoir notamment des chercheurs et des
experts intéressés par l'arrière-plan technique et la construction d'indicateurs de la sécurité des patients,
ainsi que d'autres pays désireux de développer des indicateurs de la qualité des soins et services de santé
comparables au niveau international.
TABLE OF CONTENTS
text.p:
by the US Institute of Medicine in 2000 brought
patient safety issues to the fore by presenting the magnitude and impact of patient safety problems in the
US health system in clear detail. Since then a number of other countries have released similar reports with
disturbingly similar messages for their health systems. This has put the need for improved patient safety
monitoring and accountability under the spotlight. National administrations are now responding to the
rising interest in patient safety and quality with efforts to improve measurement and reporting systems in
these areas of health care performance.
2.
To respond to country needs for internationally comparable information on indicators and data
systems for quality, the OECD initiated the OECD Health Care Quality Indicator (HCQI) Project in 2001.
The long-term objective of the HCQI Project is to develop a set of indicators that can be used to raise
questions for further investigation concerning the quality of health care across countries. In March 2006
the OECD published an initial report with data that was collected between 2003 and 2005 on an initial set
of quality indicators (Mattke S et al, 2006). The results of this initial report from the HCQI Project showed
clearly that there were only a limited number of indicators available for international comparisons for
which there was consensus on the importance and soundness of the indicators and the availability and
comparability of the data. Consequently, the OECD embarked on a new phase of work through the HCQI
Project to work collaboratively with countries on improving data systems in five priority areas, including
patient safety. A second round of data collection conducted in 2006 to support this work confirmed that
there is a paucity of available national data to meaningfully track patient safety.
3.
In part because of the lack of data and in part because of the very high level of interest across
member countries, the OECD formed an Expert Group on Patient Safety, which met for the first time
during June 2006 in Dublin, Ireland (OECD, 2007). The meeting was hosted by the Irish Department of
Health and Children and was the first multi-country conference organised by the OECD on patient safety
data systems. The conference attempted to address three issues: a) getting patient safety data systems on
the agenda; b) developing a concrete work plan for improving patient safety data systems and international
comparability of patient safety data; and c) addressing how countries should approach linking data to
action to improve patient safety.
4.
From the presentations made at the conference, it became apparent that the most readily available
set of data systems for tracking patient safety are hospital administrative data systems. It is noted that
efforts have been made in a growing number of OECD countries to adapt indicators developed in the US
which can be derived from hospital administrative data. However, it was recognized that important issues
still needed to be resolved before these indicators could be widely applied across OECD countries,
including the construction of translations between different national approaches to data coding and the
testing of indicators in the context of different country data systems.
5.
The conference concluded with a commitment to increase the potential of cross national
comparisons of patient safety through two key work initiatives focussing on:
• Adaptation of hospital administrative data systems for facilitating cross-national comparative
information of Patient Safety Indicators (PSI), and
• Reviewing adverse event reporting systems.
6.
As part of the overall effort under the first of these initiatives, this manual seeks to facilitate cross
national comparisons of indicators for patient safety through the provision of detailed practical advice on
calculating each indicator selected from a recommended set of Patient Safety Indicators (PSI) 2 utilising
national hospital administrative databases.
7.
The set of indicators selected for further analysis and specification is summarised in Table 1.

text.head: Obstetrics
text.p:
Birth trauma -injury to neonate
Obstetric trauma – vaginal delivery with instrument
Obstetric trauma – vaginal delivery without instrument
Obstetric trauma -caesarean section
8.
These indicators are a set of indicators providing information on potential in-hospital
complications and adverse events following surgeries, procedures, and childbirth. They were developed
after a comprehensive literature review, analysis of ICD-9-CM codes, clinician panel review,
implementation of risk adjustment, and empirical analyses.
9.
Methods to calculate the values of these indicators from hospital administrative data systems
have until now been carried out only on local and national levels. In this manual, several steps are outlined
to validate a methodology that could be applied internationally for data comparability. The first is a data-
text.figure:
2
The OECD HCQI Project convened a panel of experts on indicators for patient safety in 2004. Using a
structured interview process the panel came forward with a recommendation that 21 indicators be further
considered. See Millar J et al (2004).
text.p:
based research effort that focuses on examining specific data elements and coding issues that currently
impede international comparability of patient safety indicators based on hospital administrative data. Next,
an experimental calculation of indicators is to be performed by a group of volunteering countries.
10.
This manual was originally designed to support the calculation of patient safety indicators in a
group of countries volunteering to participate in the validation of the methodology. However it is
anticipated that the material presented will also be of interest to a wider audience, including researchers
and experts interested in the technical background and construction of the Patient Safety Indicators and
other countries looking to develop internationally comparable health care quality indicators.
text.head: METHODOLOGICAL ISSUES
text.p:
Introduction
13.
The methodology for facilitating internationally comparable Patient Safety Indicators set out in
this manual involves two key elements:
• Cross-walk between the key disease classifications
• Specified process of calculation
14.
The Patient Safety Indicators dealt with in this manual are specified according to certain
diagnosis and, in some instances, procedure codes. There are currently different medical classifications in
use for coding diagnosis; the ICD-9 (International Classification of Diseases) classification which is no
longer updated by the World Health Organisation (WHO) is the precursor of the present ICD-10
classification. OECD member countries use ICD-9 (e.g. Spain, USA) as well as ICD-10 (e.g. Australia,
Canada, Germany). For that reason this manual contains both versions of the coding system.
15.
Usually countries do not use the original version of a classification published by the WHO but
modify it according to their needs. Country modifications are still consistent with the WHO version,
keeping the structure of the classification tree. In some chapters of the ICD classification the country
versions are more extensive than the WHO version while in others they are not. This manual does not
cover all the different country versions of the ICD.
16.
The technical specifications of diagnosis in this manual are based on the ICD-10-WHO, 2006 and
on the ICD-9-CM 3 . Therefore countries seeking to utilise this manual must ensure that before applying the
definitions the defined codes for inclusion or exclusion criteria are currently in use. Otherwise the
definitions at hand must be extended to include the subgroups added in the country modifications.
17.
For example, Table 2 shows that one three-digit WHO code for decubitus ulcer corresponds to 8
four-digit codes in Canada, 5 four-digit codes in Australia and 50 five-digit German codes. To calculate the
numerator for the indicator decubitus ulcer, all country specific subgroups of the listed WHO code L89
must be taken into account.
text.figure:
3.
Definitions in ICD-9-CM are adopted from AHRQ (2003).

18.
text.p:
There are several criteria which are not consistent between countries that may influence the
calculated rates of the indicators. These are:

− Definition of principal diagnosis
− Definition of secondary diagnosis
• Use of diagnosis type indicators (e.g. marking of secondary diagnosis as " present at admission " )
• Use of DRG for hospital reimbursement
• Certain administrative case information
− Admission type (elective, from long-term care, transferred from acute care)
− Admission weight of neonates.
19.
A questionnaire was distributed with this manual to collect more information on the coding
specifications within each country participating in the initial experimental calculations of the indicators
(Annex 3). Participating countries were asked to fill out the questionnaire and return it to the OECD
Secretariat. The information on country specific coding specifications strongly facilitated the interpretation
of the results by the OECD Secretariat.
text.head: Cross Walking from ICD-9 to ICD-10
text.p:
20.
The quantitative relationship between ICD-9 and ICD-10 is not 1:1. The ICD-10 is much more
extensive than the ICD-9 and structures in the classification trees vary between the two. In a preliminary
German project (Drösler et al, 2007), mapping of diagnoses and procedures was performed for each
definition of the patient safety indicators (AHRQ 2004). Diagnosis mapping was performed using cross
walking tables (DIMDI, 2007) between ICD-9-WHO V6.0 and ICD-10-German Modification 2004 in two
steps, with updates of the indicator definitions appended to the translated version.
21.
ICD-10 codes were manually revised after a preliminary crosswalk. Mapped ICD-10 codes with
an unclear relationship to the original ICD-9-WHO code were compared to the ICD-9-CM, which is the
origin of the indicator definitions. ICD-10 codes with correspondents in ICD-9-CM were rejected when the
matching ICD-9-CM code had not been specified in the definition of the indicator. Transferred ICD-10
codes were accepted when the medical concept matched the intention of the indicator definition. For
example, the ICD-10 code T88.4 " Failed or difficult intubation " was included to the numerator
specification of indicator " Complications of Anaesthesia " because it was a mapped result to the
corresponding ICD-9-CM-code E87.63 " Endotracheal tube wrongly placed during anaesthetic procedure " .
22.
Due to the different country versions of the diagnosis classification, for an international project
such as the OECD Health Care Quality Indicators Project it is necessary to find a common " classification
language " . Thus the country specific ICD-10 translations of the indicator definitions have been
transformed to the ICD-10-WHO 2006 (WHO, 2006) to serve as the basis for the crosswalk. The ICD-10
codes listed in this manual underwent an international harmonisation process initiated by the International
Methodology Consortium for Coded Health Information (IMECCHI) research collaboration (Quan H et al,
2008).
text.head: Process of Calculation
text.p:
23.
The numerators pertain to subsets of the denominators. Calculate the denominator quantity first.
Then apply the numerator definition to the selected denominator data.
text.head: Exclusions of Principal Diagnosis
text.p:
24.
Verify the documentation rules for the principal diagnosis (main diagnosis, discharge diagnosis)
in use for each country is required to decide how the exclusions of the principal diagnosis should be
performed.
text.head: Definitions of Principal Diagnosis (PDx) 4
text.p:
A. The condition established after evaluation to be chiefly responsible for causing the
hospitalisation.
text.head: B.
text.p:
The diagnosis that is finally established to be the main reason for the hospital stay; that is
demanding the most resources/medical effort over the course of the patients stay.
25.
The original AHRQ patient safety manual is based on definition A (Department of Health and
Human Services, 2005). For that reason most indicator definitions contain an exclusion rule if the
principal diagnosis of the case is equal to a numerator defining ICD code. For these cases it is unlikely that
the indicator-defining condition had been acquired during the hospital stay but was pre-existing.
26.
In this manual it is assumed that countries using definition B for assignment of principal
diagnosis are able to identify the case-related admission diagnosis (ADx) in their data sets. In this case
patients with admission diagnosis corresponding to the numerator definition of the indicator should be
excluded (see left-sided flow chart " PDx algorithm " on p.14). Furthermore it shall be avoided that
countries using definition B for assignment of principal diagnosis miss numerator cases by assigning
specific complications as principal diagnosis. If a diagnosis type indicator is in use data can be properly
rearranged (see right-sided flow chart at Figure 1: PDx Algorithm).
text.head: Secondary diagnosis
text.p:
27.
Patient safety indicators are largely constructed from secondary diagnoses. The calculation of the
numerator builds on secondary diagnosis for most of the indicators. The indicator definitions refer to
conditions aroused post admission. To make sure that all participating countries use the same definition of
secondary diagnosis it is presented here:
text.head: Definition of Secondary Diagnosis (SDx) 8
text.p:
28.
Comorbid conditions are those conditions for which the patient received treatment and consumed
hospital resources in addition to those conditions considered to be the principal, main or discharge
diagnosis.
text.head:
34.
Pre-admission conditions
text.p:
without any necessary treatment during the hospital stay do not meet
the definition. Pre-admission comorbidities with in-hospital treatment meet the definition of the secondary
diagnosis. Countries using diagnosis type indicators have the possibility to distinguish between pre-and
post-admission comorbidities. If they perform additional exclusions of numerator cases their calculated
rates might be lower than in countries where additional criteria for secondary diagnosis documentation are
not in use.
text.figure: Use of codes for external causes of morbidity and mortality ( " E-codes " )
text.p:
35.
Several indicators (e.g. Complications of Anaesthesia) build on diagnoses codes from Chapter
XX (20) of the ICD-10 or the corresponding supplement of the ICD-9 respectively. The WHO designates
those codes for additional documentation of external causes of morbidity. The availability of these codes in
country modifications of the ICD may vary. Furthermore their use is optional in some countries.
Depending on the extent of available e-codes in country modifications indicator rates may vary between
countries.
text.head: Exclusions of MDC
text.p:
36.
In countries using DRG for hospital reimbursement each case is assigned to a MDC (Major
Diagnostic Category) by the grouper software. The MDC assignment relies exclusively on the principal
diagnosis of the case (definition A above).The calculation of several indicators (Table 3) requires the
exclusion of certain MDCs to ensure that whole populations with high risk for a condition are not counted.
For example, MDC 9 (diseases of skin, subcutaneous tissue, and breast) is excluded from the calculation of
indicator Decubitus Ulcer. Lists of ICD-10-WHO codes referring to certain MDCs are provided in the
Annex 2 -Code List M 5 for countries using ICD-10 without DRG reimbursement or if the MDC
assignment of data is impossible.
text.figure:
5.
Code lists and neonate identification are adapted from (InEK, 2006 and Commonwealth of Australia,
1998).
text.p:
37.
There are different methods to identify Neonates (MDC 15). If the admission weight of the
neonate and the information on age in days is available in the dataset the algorithm below should be used
for exclusion. Otherwise a code list will be provided in the Annex.
text.figure:
Algorithm for neonate identification (MDC 15) 10
1 day <age<28 days
or
27 days<age<365 days and 0 grams < weight < 2500 grams
text.head: Procedure Codes
text.p:
38.
The calculations of eight of the indicators require procedure codes. Those indicators are
" Postoperative Iatrogenic Pneumothorax " , " Postoperative Hip Fracture " " Postoperative Respiratory
Failure " " Postoperative Pulmonary Embolism (PE) or Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) " , " Obstetric Trauma
– Vaginal Delivery with / without instrument " and " Obstetric Trauma -Caesarean Section " . There is no
common international medical procedure classification and each country participating in the experimental
calculation of the indicators uses a different catalogue for procedure coding. In the project at hand it was
not possible to provide a procedure code lists for each participating country. The procedure codes from the
US ICD-9-CM are listed in this manual because they are part of the original indicator definitions provided
by AHRQ. Furthermore, the procedure list provided in this manual shall support countries in adopting
corresponding procedures from their classifications in order to perform a precise PSI calculation.
39.
Five indicators refer to denominator cases with operative treatment only. Those are:
text.table:
• Complications of Anaesthesia
• Postoperative Hip Fracture
• Postoperative Respiratory Failure
• Postoperative Pulmonary Embolism (PE) or Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)
• Postoperative Sepsis

40.
text.p:
For selection of these cases a comparison between the coded procedures and a list of all operating
room procedures available in a country's procedure classification is necessary. For the reasons explained
above it is not possible to generate lists of operating room procedures for each country. The following
interventional procedures are regarded as operative procedures: Pacemaker Implants, PTCA 6 or endoscopic
vessel repair. D&C 7 is regarded as an operating room procedure where as a perineal laceration repair
during a regular vaginal delivery is not.
text.head: Flow Charts
text.p:
41.
For each indicator a flow chart is provided to facilitate the understanding of the indicator
definition and the calculation process. For the construction of the flowcharts, definition A of the principal
diagnosis ( " condition to be chiefly responsible " ) had been assumed. Countries using definition B
( " condition demanding the most resources " ) for assignment of principal diagnosis are advised to rearrange
their data in order to gain comparable results. A proposal for rearrangement is given in the flowchart at
Figure 1: PDx Algorithm.
text.head: General Note
text.p:
42.
Data quality is always a concern in health indicator analysis that can also substantially affect
patient safety indicators. In addition to the proposed definitions, a comprehensive review of coding
practices, distribution of key data elements and country specific coding standards is strongly recommended
for data analysis of these PSIs. Given the nature of the PSIs, small sample size may lead to less precise
estimates and requires special attention when reporting these indicators. All of these factors can affect
comparability of the PSIs, and need to be addressed when making such comparisons.
text.head: Remarks on Calculation of National Rates (Population Rates) and Mean Provider Rates
text.p:
43.
The questionnaire that was distributed with this manual to each country participating in the initial
experimental calculations of the indicators (Annex 3) requested two different presentations of a country's
results:

• National rates (population rates) were requested to be reported in section VI of the
questionnaire. The national rate / population rate for each indicator is the ratio between events
(numerator) and population (denominator). The national rates (population rates) are weighted as it
is pretended that all the cases included in the calculation lie in one hospital.

• Mean provider rates were requested to be reported in section VII of the questionnaire. The
calculation of a mean provider rate requires the possibility of data analysis on an institutional level.
The mean provider rate of an indicator is the sum of the individual hospital rates for this indicator
divided by the number of hospitals where this indicator was applied.
text.head: Notes:
text.p:
• If for certain indicators, there were institutions without denominator populations (e.g. hospitals
without an obstetric department) these were to be excluded from the calculation of the mean
provider rate of that indicator.
• Indicators with rates of zero (institutions where no numerator defining event occurred within a
given denominator population) were to be included in the calculation of the mean provider rate.
• Cases treated in psychiatric institutions were to be excluded from the calculation.
6.
Percutaneous Transluminal Coronary Angioplasty, an intervention in cardiology.
7.
Dilation and Curettage, a gynaecological or obstetric treatment.
text.head: Quick Step Overview of Essential Tasks for Data Preparation
text.p:
The following outlines the key steps in preparing data for the calculation of the Patient Safety Indicators:
1. Convert listed ICD codes to your country's version of ICD
2. Look up in your ICD classification if there are codes available for SIRS (Systemic Inflammatory
Response syndrome). If these codes are available add them to the numerator inclusion list of the
text.head: indicator Postoperative Sepsis
text.p:
3. Look up in your ICD classification if there are codes available for Iatrogenic Pneumothorax. If
these codes are available add them to the numerator inclusion list of the indicator Iatrogenic
Pneumothorax
text.head: 4. Look up the procedure codes
text.table:
in use in your country procedure classification for the following
procedures:
a. " Interruption of Vena Cava "
Add a) to the denominator calculation of indicator Postoperative Pulmonary Embolism
(PE) or Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).
b. " Obstetric Trauma "
Add b) to the numerator calculation of all Obstetric Trauma indicators.
c. " Caesarean Delivery "
Use c) to select the denominator population of indicator Obstetric Trauma –Caesarean
Section Deliveries.
d. " Instrument-Assisted Delivery procedure codes "
Use d) to select the denominator population of indicator Obstetric Trauma -Vaginal
Delivery with Instrument
e. " Hip fracture repair "
Cases with e) are excluded from the denominator population of indicator Postoperative
Hip Fracture if
text.p:
the hip fracture repair occurs before or on the same day as the first
operating room procedure.
f. " Endotracheal (re-)intubation
Cases with f) are in the numerator population of indicator Postoperative Respiratory
Failure if the reintubation occurs after the main OR procedure
g. " Diaphragmatic surgery repair, thoracic and cardiac surgery, lung or pleural biopsy " (page.
22, Annex 1 -Code List P)
Add g) to the denominator exclusion of indicator Iatrogenic Pneumothorax
5. Check the definition of principal diagnosis (PDx) applied in your country
6. If the PDx definition is " the condition to be chiefly responsible " proceed to step 7. If the PDx
definition is " the condition demanding the most resources " , rearrange the data as shown in the
flowchart at Figure 1: PDx Algorithm.
7. Flag cases with OR (operating room) procedures designated as " surgical " . A comprehensive list of
OR procedures must be provided by your country.
8. Apply calculation algorithm to each case as shown in the indicator-related flowcharts.

DETAILED DEFINITIONS OF INDICATORS
Complications of Anaesthesia, Secondary Diagnosis Field per 100 Discharges (PSI 1)
44.
There are validity concerns about this indicator and thus should be used with precaution. It is
unclear, whether this indicator is consistently related to adverse outcomes. In US data (Zhan and Miller,
2003) this indicator was associated with excess charges but not with excess mortality or length of stay.
Numerator:
45.
Discharges with ICD-9-CM diagnosis codes for anaesthesia complications in any secondary
diagnosis field among cases meeting the inclusion and exclusion rules for the denominator.

52.
The WHO version of the ICD-10 does not contain a specific ICD-code for iatrogenic
pneumothorax. Several countries assigned a code for this condition in their country version of the ICD-10.
Before starting the calculation, check whether your country version contains the specified code (e.g. a five
digit code in J95.-). If your country-specific ICD-10 version does not contain a defined code related to
iatrogenic pneumothorax abandon this indicator.

• With any procedure code indicating thoracic surgery, lung or pleural biopsy, or cases assigned to
cardiac surgery

Postoperative Hip Fracture, Secondary Diagnosis Field per 100 Discharges (PSI 8)
56.
There are validity concerns about this indicator and thus should be used with precaution.
Previous unpublished studies showed that this indicator might capture pre-admission hip fractures as well
as the in-patient complication.
Numerator:
57.
Discharges with ICD code for hip fracture in any secondary diagnosis field among cases meeting
the inclusion and exclusion rules for the denominator.
ICD-9-CM Hip Fracture diagnosis codes (includes all 5 th digits)
8200

8201

8203

S72.1

S72.2

Note: ICD-10-WHO optionally offers additional subdivisions for S72.-. Include all 5 th digit codes when in
use.
Note: If it is possible to distinguish between a pre-admission condition and a post-admission condition by
using a diagnosis type indicator, only conditions that occurred post-admission should be counted. The rate
will be lower when this criterion is used.
Denominator
58.
All surgical discharges age 18 and older with a code for an operating room procedure.

• Where a procedure for hip fracture repair occurs before or on the same day as the first operating
room procedure
o Note: If day of procedure is not available in the input data file, the rate may be slightly
lower than if the information was available
• With diseases and disorders of the musculoskeletal system and connective tissue (MDC 8) or
principal diagnosis in Annex 2 -Code List M-1
• With principal diagnosis (or secondary diagnosis present on admission, if known) of seizure,
syncope, stroke, coma, cardiac arrest, poisoning, trauma, delirium and other psychoses, or anoxic
brain injury
• With any diagnosis of metastatic cancer, lymphoid malignancy or bone malignancy, or self-
inflicted injury
• MDC14 (pregnancy, childbirth, and puerperium) or principal diagnosis in
Annex 2 -Code List M-

70.
All liveborn births (newborns).
71.
The definition of newborn is any neonate with either:
1) A diagnosis code for an in-hospital liveborn birth or
2) An admission type of newborn, age in days at admission equal to zero, and not an ICD-9-CM
diagnosis code for an out-of-hospital birth.
72.
A neonate is defined as any discharge with age in days at admission between zero and 28 days
(inclusive). If age in days is missing, then a neonate is defined as any DRG in MDC 15 (ICD-10-WHO
code list in Annex 2 -Code List M-4) and an admission type of newborn, or a diagnosis code for an in-
hospital liveborn birth. Another option for identification of an in hospital birth may be the age in days at
admission is 0 and the admission type is not transferred from another acute care facility.
